A recent Investors.com article emphasizes that the best leaders don't just share knowledge; they challenge assumptions, foster curiosity, and offer insights that help others grow.

True leadership is about adding value. Are your contributions sparking meaningful discussions? Are your ideas encouraging innovation and action, or are they just adding to the noise?

How are you shaping the conversations that truly matter?

The 1980s was a decade full of unforgettable moments, and the sounds of that time were just as iconic. These nostalgic memories transport us to a simpler yet exciting era:

 The satisfying click and whir of rewinding a cassette tape.
ï¸ The sharp ring of a rotary phone, signaling important conversations.
 The mechanical grind of a floppy disk drive loading up important files.
ï¸ The cheerful beep-boop of arcade games that sparked hours of fun.
 The nostalgic static hiss of a TV antenna being adjusted for the perfect signal.

Each sound brings back memories of innovation, fun, and discovery. From music and gaming to early tech, the 80s shaped much of what we cherish today.

Which iconic sound from the past sparks nostalgia for you, even if you didnâ€™t experience it firsthand? Letâ€™s relive the magic together in the comments! 

 Follow me for more nostalgic moments and timeless stories!

The nostalgic sound of arcade games always makes me smile

posts.name:
Steve Litzow
Steve Litzow
posts.content:
Big deal about to close... but itâ€™s not the ICP?

When I work on refining sales strategies for scale ups, I always include a validation step.

It comes after the proposal and negotiation.

Itâ€™s an internal step for:
â€“ The CEO or VP of Sales to review the deal.
â€“ The SDR or sales manager to self-analyze.
â€“ An item to discuss during weekly or monthly deal reviews.

The key focus of validation?

Double-check the customer still fits your ICP.

Itâ€™s overlooked because:
â€“ The SDR wants to hit quota.
â€“ The sales manager wants to hit quota.
â€“ Or simply, the revenue is too tempting to resist.

But if youâ€™re serious about scaling to 8 or 9 figures, you must take this step.

You must reconsider going ahead if the ICP isnâ€™t the right fit.

Hereâ€™s whyâ€¦

I recently read a story from Jake Fuentes, co-founder of Cascade, about why he shut his startup down.

He admitted that â€œICP frayâ€ was a key factor.

Cascade initially defined their ICP as â€œnontechnical business analysts using Excel to crunch big data setsâ€.

The definition was too broad.

They ended up chasing customers with wildly different use cases:
â€“ A scooter company managing location data.
â€“ An HR team managing employee data.

They didnâ€™t have a framework to accept or reject opportunities, so they tried to support them all.

Jake described this as â€œa slow death of a thousand cuts.â€

Supporting anyone and everyone pulled the company in a million directions, ultimately diluting their focus and stunting growth.

If you want to scale successfully, rejecting deals from prospects who donâ€™t fit your ICP is the tough but necessary way forward.

Validate every deal.

Stick to your guns.

Keep closing.

Like what you read? ï¸ Repost it to your network and follow Steve Litzow for more.

Want to accelerate your sales? Join our community of CEOs & Sales Leaders subscribers today:

comments.commentText: Staying true to your ICP is crucial for growth. Misaligned deals might boost short-term revenue but often lead to inefficiencies and lost focus. Discipline here pays dividends!

posts.content:
Global Impact
7, 8, and 9 Figure Success
Authentic Friendship

These are three bold values found in many Black Executive Men Community membersâ€™ conversations, aspirations, and achievements.

Black Executive Men Community
Q1 Ohio Regional Social, January 16th, 2025

Moving from the lone wolf mentalityâ€”priding oneself on doing everything aloneâ€”to a corporate community mentality, we embrace meaningful connection and mutual support to help each man go further in life.

In fact, we are stronger together.

As Black men with histories that range from challenging to spectacular, we may not have all the answers as individuals, but together we do.

And that means spending quality time:
- Talking
- Sharing
- Leading
- Trusting
- Learning
- Listening
- Laughing
- Supporting
- Andâ€¦ Caring

We know that where trust grows, business flows.
- Careers flow
- Investments flow
- New Partnerships flow

With facilitated socials just like this happening across 22 cities in the US and UK on the same night and time, weâ€™re not only providing ourselves with a good time but also cultivating strategic networking abilities that translate to greater career, business, and lifestyle success.

I hope this picture reminds you of the millions of corporate and entrepreneurial Black men all over the worldâ€”just like me, just like usâ€”dedicated to ensuring that our organizations and families are guided well.

We are Black Executive Men Community, and weâ€™re here to unlock our full leadership potential.

Join us today:

posts.name:
Christian Krause
Christian Krause
posts.content:
There's zero risk in cold calling a prospect.

The worst that can happen

â€¢ You talk to the wrong person
â†’ 1 step closer to the right one

â€¢ You get some objections
â†’ opportunity for discovery

â€¢ You get hung up on
â†’ whoops, it can happen

â€¢ You get yelled at
â†’ fire these prospects

Whatever happens, it's better than bumping your email with "thoughts?" for the 11th time.

I hope this will take away some people's fears around cold calling.

Just get comfortable with the uncomfortable.

Trust me: you'll book more meetings faster.

What's your opinion on cold calling?

posts.name:
Jessica Paul
Jessica Paul
posts.content:
It takes commitment to build a business, it takes 10x MORE to build a community â†´

Hear me out.

Building a business is NOT the same as building a community. They both require a different focus and perspective.

I know some fantastic entrepreneurs who are also building amazing communities.

But they are not the same thing.


Building a business is:

- for you
- revenue focussed
- team centred


Building a community is:

- for them
- â€˜feelingâ€™ focussed
- relationship centred


Frankly, in this day and age the fastest way to grow your business is to build a community. And this is where some people get a little confused.

STOP selling, START sharing.

In other words, build a community that loves you and the rest will follow. This requires commitment to others. It requires you to be selfless. It requires you to sometimes put someone else before your own goals for a change.

THIS is what community really means.

And itâ€™s also what distinguishes a good personal brand, from a GREAT one.

So get building.

(This is something Iâ€™m going to be able to help you with very soon )


What are your best tips for building a strong community? Let me know in the comments!


P.S on that note, Iâ€™m forever grateful for this growing community on LinkedIn (over 20k of you now!) If you want to join in, give mea follow for more on personal branding, PR and how to really stand out.

And repost this if it resonated.ï¸

comments.commentText: Absolutely love this perspective, Jessica! Building a community truly transforms the way we connect and grow. My top tip? Always listen firstâ€”understanding your community's needs and passions creates a strong foundation for meaningful relationships. Excited to see how you help us all build even stronger connections!
